section.title: FHIR Implementation for Patient Safety
section.para: This chapter identifies a set of options involving FHIR implementation constructs and approaches that can leverage to improve the semantic precision of FHIR resources using Solor-based semantic constraints.

section.title: Background
section.para: Similar to other interoperability standards, HL7 Fast Healthcare Interoperability Resources (FHIR) provide a great of flexibility to implementers: a choice of services, optional data elements, minimal terminology constraints, and extensions – including modifiers – are wide open. However, while flexibility is useful to promote standards adoption, it leads to ambiguity, lack of semantic consistency, and poor patient outcomes. Therefore, successful standards implementations that support patient safety require rigorous conformance using profiles organized into implementation guides.

section.title: FHIR Conformance Methodology
section.para:
The concept of “profiling” a standard for a use case and to address specific requirements it used broadly standards like DICOM, NCPDP, and HL7 message, document, resources. Best-practices over the past decades define a profile (or template) as an unambiguous specification of a standard structure that has been analyzed for particular set of requirements. It prescribes a set of precise constraints upon the standard thus ensuring the implementation is testable and the semantics are precise. The constraints affect the presence, occurrences, and meaning of the data elements. Since FHIR is also a standard-based Application Programming Interface and a Data Services standards, conformance also describes the services supported by a FHIR server. FHIR conformance is documented using FHIR several definitional resources:
ImplementationGuide: this resource is used todescribe an implementation guide and references any profiles including extensions required by to meet the purpose of the implementation guide.
StructureDefinition: this resurce to describe profiles of FHIR resources that contain how data elements, references, and extensions are supposed to instantiated. Profiles provide terminology bindings for coded data elements – using ValueSet resources. Conformance predicates to validate FHIR based on CIMI models and Solor could be created using FHIRPath.
ValueSet: this resources is used to describe a value set. Value sets reference concepts specified CodeSystem including external code systems like SNOMED CT, LOINC, RxNorm, etc.

Profiling FHIR can more effective a family of a profiles are derived from a common set of base profiles as seen in . This methodology ensures that organizations and vendors are able to adopt common/national requirements. Similarly, an organization like VA could create a set of profiles derived from national profiles. Project and application may create further specializations of organization profiles that inherit the base profiles specifications. FHIR allows implementation guides to redefine what it means to support a data element. It allows VA to create profiles and implementation guides that are explicitly intended to promote patient safety.

The US Core Implementation Guide introduces a reusable set of profiles that address national regulatory requirements (i.e. Meaningful Use 2015). US implementers can use them as the starting point for additional constraints or extensions. For instance, the VA may create extension specific to military service, Veteran care to ensure interoperability with DoD and other community providers. The only way to accomplish this level of patient-centered information exchange is to create precise implementation guides that leverage Solor. Since standards represent a union of data and interoperability requirements, implementers need to constrain or extend a standard consistent with their requirements. The more constrained and precise a profile, the more likely it is that resources that conform to those profiles will be semantically interoperable. such that the source and consuming system interpret the data in same way and present it to clinicians in the same context. Common meaning requires common semantics, assumptions, and data elements. Profiles are therefore the must-have element of successful implementation.

FHIR conformance concepts and resources that were approved as Normative in FHIR Release 5 (January 2019). This fact provides a stable foundation for creating implementation guides, profile, and value sets that illustrate best practices for semantic interoperability. Such example profiles and resources can guide a next generation of application developers and integrators. FHIR is an emerging a specification information exchange and for application development and systems built from the ground up on standard-based concepts.

section.title: HL7 engagement: FHIR implementations using Solor
section.para:
Based on an analysis of FHIR Release 4 and considering the roadmap for Release 5, there several important options to employ Solor in FHIR implementation guide development:
FHIR conformance provides a mechanism to eliminate ambiguity, increase precision, and manage extensions. Filter-based, enumerated, and aggregated value sets are support by Terminology Servers. Solor assemblages could become the basis for FHIR ValueSets that use rigorous versioning based on globally-unique canonical identifiers.
All the resources needed to implement FHIR have reached Normative status in Release 4. Only two business-related resource have reached that status: Observation and Patient. Other resources are still in “Trial Use” and will reach Normative status after 2020. The VA could leverage Solor to propose value set bindings that improve the clarity of FHIR resources and US-realm profiles managed by the US Realm Taskforce.
The VA will also be responsible for managing/governance of VA-specific profiles and implementation guides. Solor assemblages may be used to provide precise vocabulary bindings for coded data elements needed to address VA-specific requirements.
Solor and CIMI models may be used to specify FHIR profile and data validation predicates using FHIRPath: standard-based, platform-neutral navigation and data validation language using syntax-generator(ANTLR) grammar. FHIRPath is standard-based notation already used to specify invariant for FHIR resources. It is also applicable to conformance predicates, logical expressions, and filters. It can be used to express additinal contrainst on data capture and validation rules can be specified and processed are runtime. FHIR Resource Invariant
Future work to produce SNOMED CT value sets using Solor assemblages is permitted under the agreement HL7 and IHTSDO. Publishing best-practices as value sets, implementation guides, and profiles will improve the quality treatment data such that it’s can be shared among provider to improve outcomes and promote patient safety.
